result.markdown:
--- title: France Grid --- The goal of this repository is to execute and document a data pipeline for aspects of the French electrical grid. These are data made available publicly via [APIs from RTE France](https://data.rte-france.com/). I understand [RTE France's terms and conditions](https://data.rte-france.com/cgu) allow for republication, so long as the data are credited to RTE France, and are not distorted. When finished, this site will publish tables as parquet files: - generation sources, e.g. wind, solar - exchanges with other countries, e.g. England, Belgium - outdoor temperature in Paris (I know there's more to France than Paris) Using GitHub Actions, these tables will be updated daily. This will also be an opportunity for me to learn to use: - [Requests](https://requests.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) - [Polars](https://www.pola.rs/) - [DVC](https://dvc.org/) - [Quarto](https://quarto.org/) using Python with `.qmd` files ## Secrets To interact with the APIs and data-storage, the code in this report will expect certain environment variables to be set: - `AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID`, `AWS_ACCESS_KEY_SECRET`: can also be set using `aws cli` - `RTE_FRANCE_BASE64` base-64 encoding available from RTE application-page These allow you access to an application (that you will have to configure on your RTE France account); this application will need access to these APIs: - [Actual Generation](https://data.rte-france.com/catalog/-/api/generation/Actual-Generation/v1.1) - [Physical Flow](https://data.rte-france.com/catalog/-/api/exchanges/Physical-Flow/v1.0) ## Data pipeline ::: {.cell execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import polars as pl from pyprojroot.here import here import subprocess ``` ::: This flowchart is generated using DVC: ```{mermaid} flowchart TD node1["flow-ingest"] node2["flow-publish"] node3["flow-transform"] node4["generation-ingest"] node5["generation-publish"] node6["generation-transform"] node7["index"] node1-->node3 node2-->node7 node3-->node2 node4-->node6 node5-->node7 node6-->node5 ``` ### Generation ::: {.cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} generation = pl.read_parquet(here("data/99-publish/standard/generation.parquet")) ``` ::: Two files parquet files are published, each with the same information: - [Standard](/data/99-publish/standard/generation.parquet) - [Fake-UTC](/data/99-publish/fake-utc/generation.parquet) The last few observations: ::: {.cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} generation.tail() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ```{=html}
shape: (5, 4)
typeinterval_startinterval_endgeneration
strdatetime[ms, Europe/Paris]datetime[ms, Europe/Paris]i64
"HYDRO"2018-02-24 23:45:00 CET2018-02-25 00:00:00 CET1224
"NUCLEAR"2018-02-24 23:45:00 CET2018-02-25 00:00:00 CET52942
"PUMPING"2018-02-24 23:45:00 CET2018-02-25 00:00:00 CET-7
"SOLAR"2018-02-24 23:45:00 CET2018-02-25 00:00:00 CET0
"WIND"2018-02-24 23:45:00 CET2018-02-25 00:00:00 CET7155
``` ::: ::: - `type`: type of generation - `interval_start`, `interval_end`: date-times describing the interval - `generation`: average (?) of generation during this interval (MW) We count the number of observations and null values for the generation files (will be the same for both): ::: {.cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} generation.groupby(pl.col("type")).agg( pl.col("interval_start").min(), pl.col("interval_end").max(), pl.col("generation").count().alias("n_observations"), pl.col("generation").null_count().alias("n_value_null"), ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=5} ```{=html}
shape: (10, 5)

"FOSSIL_HARD_COâ€¦2017-01-01 00:00:00 CET2018-02-25 00:00:00 CET403160

``` ::: ::: I don't know, right now, why `"HYDRO"` has one-fewer observation than the others - I'll try to find out! ::: {.cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} generation.groupby(pl.col("interval_start")).agg( pl.col("generation").count().alias("n_observations") ).sort(pl.col("n_observations")).head(2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=6} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: I don't think this was at the end of a API call... ### Flow ::: {.cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} flow = pl.read_parquet(here("data/99-publish/standard/flow.parquet")) ``` ::: Two files parquet files are published, each with the same information: - [Standard](/data/99-publish/standard/flow.parquet) - [Fake-UTC](/data/99-publish/fake-utc/flow.parquet) The last few observations: ::: {.cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} flow.tail() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=8} ```{=html}
shape: (5, 4)
partnerinterval_startinterval_endflow_net
strdatetime[ms, Europe/Paris]datetime[ms, Europe/Paris]i64
"England-IFA"2017-04-22 23:00:00 CEST2017-04-23 00:00:00 CEST-1714
"Germany"2017-04-22 23:00:00 CEST2017-04-23 00:00:00 CEST1080
"Italy"2017-04-22 23:00:00 CEST2017-04-23 00:00:00 CEST-1118

"Switzerland"2017-04-22 23:00:00 CEST2017-04-23 00:00:00 CEST-161
``` ::: ::: - `partner`: interchange, usually a country - `interval_start`, `interval_end`: date-times describing the interval - `flow`: average (?) of power flow, during this interval (MW) - positive means France received power We count the number of observations and null values for the generation files (will be the same for both): ::: {.cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} flow.groupby(pl.col("partner")).agg( pl.col("interval_start").min(), pl.col("interval_end").max(), pl.col("flow_net").count().alias("n_observations"), pl.col("flow_net").null_count().alias("n_value_null"), ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=9} ```{=html}
